prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on previous ALMA observations of CO and other lines in similar targets on similar scales, the stronger spectral lines for the science targets are expected to be up to ~4 km/s wide or so. The specified spectral line window set-ups, which all have spectral averaging factors of 2, should yield velocity widths of < 0.2 km/s. This still allows some scope for averaging of the data up to the 1 km/s to increase the per-channel s/n level (as assumed in the provided s/n calculations), should the lines be somewhat weaker than assumed here. We also include a single TDM spectral window to provide both continuum data and the requisite aggregate bandwidth for standard calibrations.

Assuming that the radius of the target disks is about 100 AU, and the distance is 140 pc, the angular size of the disks is approximately 1.4".
The goal of the proposed observations is to resolve the disks and derive their inclinations and orientations with respect to the cloud, binary and magnetic field axes. We therefore specify a desired angular resolution of 0.12" at Band 6 in order to obtain the best possible angular resolution available to standard-mode 12-m array configurations.
Given the paucity of prior high angular resolution imaging information available for the science targets, there is some limited scope for uncertainty in the size of the targeted disks and any associated structure in their immediate surroundings. We have consequently specified the largest angular structure value possible for our proposed observations, without requiring the use of a second 12-m array configuration.

Based on similar published ALMA observations of similar sightlines, we adopt a pessimistic representative peak line flux density of 100 mJy for all three sources. In case some of the targeted lines are weaker than assumed here, we also allow for the possibility of rebinning the resultant spectra to a velocity resolution of 1 km/s.
Under the above assumptions, we adopt a desired sensitivity per pointing value of 3 mJy for our proposed Band 6 observations, this should result in a S/N on the representative line of ~33, or a S/N ~5 on a 15 mJy line. These sensitivity specifications should ensure a higher S/N for both the stronger CO line and continuum maps, which are the primary science drivers for this proposal.

Based on previous ALMA observations of CO and HCO+ lines in similar targets on similar scales, the stronger spectral lines for the science targets are expected to be up to ~4 km/s wide or so. The specified spectral line window set-ups, which all have spectral averaging factors of 2, should yield velocity widths of < 0.5 km/s. This still allows some scope for averaging of the data up to the 1 km/s to increase the per-channel s/n level (as assumed in the provided s/n calculations), should the lines be somewhat weaker than assumed here. We also include a single TDM spectral window to provide both continuum data and the requisite aggregate bandwidth for standard calibrations.

Assuming that the radius of the target disks is about 100 AU, and the distance is 140 pc, the angular size of the disks is approximately 1.4".
The goal of the proposed observations is to resolve the disks and derive their inclinations and orientations with respect to the cloud, binary and magnetic field axes. We therefore specify a desired angular resolution of 0.08" at Band 7 in order to obtain the best possible angular resolution available to standard-mode 12-m array configurations.
Given the paucity of prior high angular resolution imaging information available for the science targets, there is some limited scope for uncertainty in the size of the targeted disks and any associated structure in their immediate surroundings. We have consequently specified the largest angular structure value possible for our proposed observations, without requiring the use of a second 12-m array configuration.
Due to the anticipated angular separation of the two binary components for Source A (5.8"), a small mosaic (10"x10") is needed for this field source at Band 7.

We assume that HCO+ is a representative strength for the supplementary lines targeted. Based on similar published ALMA observations of similar sightlines, we adopt a pessimistic representative peak line flux density of 100 mJy for all three sources (the CO lines are expected to be significantly stronger). In case some of the targeted supplementary lines are weaker than assuming here, we also allow for the possibility of rebinning the resultant spectra to a velocity resolution of 1 km/s.
Under the above assumptions, we adopt a desired sensitivity per pointing value of 3 mJy for our proposed Band 7 observations, which should yield a S/N on the representative line of ~33, or a S/N ~5 on a 15 mJy line. These sensitivity specifications should ensure a S/N significantly better for both the stronger CO line and continuum maps, which are the primary science drivers for this proposal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Protoplanetary disks are an important phase between star and planet formation. ALMA has proven to have the capabilities to look at the detailed structure and chemical contents of nearby protoplanetary disks around young stars. L1642 is one of the two high galactic latitude (|b| > 30 deg) clouds known to have star formation. The cloud is situated at the head of a cometary structure at a distance of ~140 pc, and it has very low line-of-sight contamination. L1642 contains a dense cold core and a chain of YSOs, including two T Tauri binaries (one of them a variable star), in different evolutionary stages. This system offers a unique opportunity to study star and protoplanetary disk formation in a constrained environment. We aim to use Band 6 and 7 continuum and line observations to detect the discs and determine their masses, stage of evolution, and orientation compared to the large-scale cloud structure and the magnetic field geometry.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
